I just want to point out something about his logic that really bothers me. He says they're 10% less efficient, and says that's the same as having to work 10% harder, but that's simply not the case.

Efficiency is the ratio of work done to energy required. If they are 10% less efficient, then that can be expressed as 90/100.

If they have to work 10% harder, then the ratio would be expressed as 100/110

90/100 is not the same as 100/110.

This sort of mistake is all too common.

Obviously, 10% is a rough estimate in this case, and the difference between 90/100 and 100/110 is insignificant, but that's not the point. The point is that people need to understand how ratios work, and that the % change in the numerator is never equivalent to the % change in the denominator. Even when they're close, assuming them to be the same is bad practice.

I think that scales on butterfly wings acts like turbolators. The characteristic Reynolds number of wing is quite low, therefore a separation of the laminar boundary layer could be very inefficient. Scales anticipate the transition from a laminar to a turbulent boundary layer on the wings, then separation is more easily retarded and consequently drag is reduced.

10% more effecient = 10% less batery = less weight of batery = less energy needed which in turn = even less battery weight    in other words it is a type of feedback loop effect. 10% more effecient turns out to be a big deal-bigger than just 10%.
